paths.title: IUI With Partner Sperm
paths.description: Intrauterine insemination using sperm from your partner - available as natural cycle (OPK monitoring) or medicated cycle (trigger shot protocol)
paths.suitable_for: Couples with unexplained infertility, mild male factor, or ovulation issues

steps.overview: Complete fertility evaluation including medical history, diagnostic testing, and required infectious disease screening. Your doctor will review your test results and determine if IUI is the right treatment for you.
Choose between natural cycle monitoring (tracking your own ovulation) or medicated cycle (using fertility medications). Complete baseline assessment to confirm you are ready to start treatment.
Track your cycle through at-home ovulation tests or clinic monitoring appointments. If using medications, take fertility drugs for 5 days and receive a trigger shot when your egg is ready.

Sperm is collected (from partner) or thawed (from donor) and processed in the lab to concentrate the healthiest sperm. The prepared sperm is then placed directly into your uterus through a quick, painless procedure.

Wait approximately two weeks after the IUI, then return for a blood pregnancy test. Your doctor will discuss next steps based on the results, whether continuing treatment or transitioning to prenatal care.

paths.title: IUI With Donor Sperm
paths.description: Intrauterine insemination using donor sperm - available as natural cycle (OPK monitoring) or medicated cycle (trigger shot protocol)
paths.suitable_for: Single individuals, same-sex couples, or severe male factor infertility

steps.overview: Complete fertility evaluation including medical history, diagnostic testing, and required infectious disease screening. Your doctor will review your test results and determine if IUI is the right treatment for you.
Review donor options, complete required counseling about using donor sperm, and handle legal documentation. You will select a donor that meets your preferences and requirements.
Choose between natural cycle monitoring (tracking your own ovulation) or medicated cycle (using fertility medications). Complete baseline assessment to confirm you are ready to start treatment.
Track your cycle through at-home ovulation tests or clinic monitoring appointments. If using medications, take fertility drugs for 5 days and receive a trigger shot when your egg is ready.

Sperm is collected (from partner) or thawed (from donor) and processed in the lab to concentrate the healthiest sperm. The prepared sperm is then placed directly into your uterus through a quick, painless procedure.

Wait approximately two weeks after the IUI, then return for a blood pregnancy test. Your doctor will discuss next steps based on the results, whether continuing treatment or transitioning to prenatal care.

paths.title: IVF With Own Eggs & Partner Sperm
paths.description: In vitro fertilization using your own eggs and partner sperm, with fertilization method (conventional or ICSI) determined by your doctor based on sperm quality and other factors
paths.suitable_for: Couples with tubal factor, endometriosis, male factor infertility, failed IUI, or unexplained infertility who are using their own fresh eggs and partner sperm

steps.overview: Complete fertility evaluation including medical history, comprehensive testing, infectious disease screening, and detailed counseling about the IVF process, success rates, and what to expect.
Your doctor selects the best medication protocol for your situation. Complete baseline ultrasound and bloodwork to confirm you are ready to start. Learn how to administer your fertility medications.

Take daily fertility medication injections for 8-12 days to stimulate your ovaries to produce multiple eggs. Attend regular monitoring appointments (ultrasounds and bloodwork) so your doctor can adjust medications and track egg development.
When your eggs are mature (follicles reach 17-20mm), you will receive a precisely-timed trigger shot to complete final egg maturation. Egg retrieval is scheduled exactly 35-36 hours later.

Under light sedation, your doctor uses ultrasound guidance to retrieve eggs from your ovaries through a thin needle. The procedure takes 15-30 minutes. You will rest in recovery for 1-2 hours before going home.

Sperm is collected and prepared. Mature eggs are fertilized using conventional IVF (mixing sperm and eggs together). The next day, the embryologist checks to see how many eggs fertilized successfully.

Fertilized eggs (embryos) are cultured in the lab for 3-6 days. The embryology team monitors their development daily and grades their quality. If you are doing genetic testing (PGT), embryos are biopsied on day 5-6.

Your doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into your uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. This is a quick, painless procedure. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use.
topic_refs: Fresh Embryo Transfer - Day Five (Blastocyst Stage)

steps.overview: Begin progesterone supplementation to support the uterine lining. Wait 9-14 days after transfer, then return for a blood pregnancy test. If pregnant, you will have early monitoring ultrasounds before graduating to regular prenatal care.

paths.title: IVF With Personal Eggs & Donor Sperm
paths.description: IVF using your own eggs and donor sperm - includes protocol selection (GnRH antagonist vs agonist), mandatory counseling, and conventional IVF fertilization (preferred over ICSI for donor sperm)
paths.suitable_for: Single individuals or couples with severe male factor infertility

steps.overview: Meet with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals and timeline. Complete fertility testing to assess your current fertility potential and determine the best preservation approach for your situation.

Complete required infectious disease screening and medical history review. Sign informed consent documents outlining the freezing process, storage options, and future use of your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos.
Provide a semen sample through ejaculation in a private collection room. If needed, multiple samples can be collected on different days to maximize the amount of sperm stored.

Complete storage consent forms and set up annual storage fee payments. Discuss whether additional freezing cycles are recommended based on your age and goals. Review the process for using your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos in the future.

paths.title: IVF With Donor Eggs
paths.description: IVF using eggs from a donor - available as fresh donor cycle (synchronization required) or frozen donor eggs (no synchronization). ICSI required for frozen eggs, mandatory counseling and legal representation.
paths.suitable_for: Advanced maternal age, poor egg quality, diminished ovarian reserve, or genetic concerns

steps.overview: Meet with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals and timeline. Complete fertility testing to assess your current fertility potential and determine the best preservation approach for your situation.

Complete required infectious disease screening and medical history review. Sign informed consent documents outlining the freezing process, storage options, and future use of your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos.
Take daily fertility medication injections for 8-12 days to stimulate your ovaries. Attend regular monitoring appointments so your doctor can track egg development and adjust medications as needed.
Under light sedation, your doctor retrieves eggs from your ovaries using ultrasound guidance. The procedure takes 15-30 minutes, followed by 1-2 hours of recovery time.

paths.title: Double Donation IVF
paths.description: IVF using both donor eggs and donor sperm - includes genetic matching between donors to prevent 300+ genetic diseases. Highest success rates with 98% cumulative pregnancy rate after 3 cycles. ICSI required for optimal fertilization.
paths.suitable_for: Couples with both partners having fertility issues, same-sex couples, single individuals, or genetic concerns requiring dual donor screening

steps.overview: Complete fertility evaluation including medical history, comprehensive testing, infectious disease screening, and detailed counseling about the IVF process, success rates, and what to expect.
Your doctor selects the best medication protocol for your situation. Complete baseline ultrasound and bloodwork to confirm you are ready to start. Learn how to administer your fertility medications.

Take daily fertility medication injections for 8-12 days to stimulate your ovaries to produce multiple eggs. Attend regular monitoring appointments (ultrasounds and bloodwork) so your doctor can adjust medications and track egg development.
When your eggs are mature (follicles reach 17-20mm), you will receive a precisely-timed trigger shot to complete final egg maturation. Egg retrieval is scheduled exactly 35-36 hours later.

Under light sedation, your doctor uses ultrasound guidance to retrieve eggs from your ovaries through a thin needle. The procedure takes 15-30 minutes. You will rest in recovery for 1-2 hours before going home.

Sperm is collected and prepared. Mature eggs are fertilized using conventional IVF (mixing sperm and eggs together). The next day, the embryologist checks to see how many eggs fertilized successfully.

Fertilized eggs (embryos) are cultured in the lab for 3-6 days. The embryology team monitors their development daily and grades their quality. If you are doing genetic testing (PGT), embryos are biopsied on day 5-6.

Your doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into your uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. This is a quick, painless procedure. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use.

paths.title: Reciprocal IVF
paths.description: Shared motherhood - one partner provides eggs (biological mother), the other carries pregnancy (gestational mother). Requires cycle synchronization and allows fresh embryo transfer. 2024 legal changes removed enhanced screening requirements.
paths.suitable_for: Same-sex female couples wanting both partners involved biologically, LGBTQ+ couples seeking shared motherhood experience

steps.overview: Complete fertility evaluation including medical history, comprehensive testing, infectious disease screening, and detailed counseling about the IVF process, success rates, and what to expect.
Your doctor selects the best medication protocol for your situation. Complete baseline ultrasound and bloodwork to confirm you are ready to start. Learn how to administer your fertility medications.

paths.title: IVF With Gestational Carrier (Surrogacy)
paths.description: Using a surrogate to carry your pregnancy
paths.suitable_for: Absent/abnormal uterus, medical conditions, or recurrent pregnancy loss

steps.overview: Complete fertility evaluation including medical history, comprehensive testing, infectious disease screening, and detailed counseling about the IVF process, success rates, and what to expect.
Your doctor selects the best medication protocol for your situation. Complete baseline ultrasound and bloodwork to confirm you are ready to start. Learn how to administer your fertility medications.

Take daily fertility medication injections for 8-12 days to stimulate your ovaries to produce multiple eggs. Attend regular monitoring appointments (ultrasounds and bloodwork) so your doctor can adjust medications and track egg development.

Your doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into your uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. This is a quick, painless procedure. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use.

Begin progesterone supplementation to support the uterine lining. Wait 9-14 days after transfer, then return for a blood pregnancy test. If pregnant, you will have early monitoring ultrasounds before graduating to regular prenatal care.

paths.title: Sperm Freezing
paths.description: Preserve male fertility by freezing sperm
paths.suitable_for: Before cancer treatment, vasectomy, or advancing age

steps.overview: Meet with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals and timeline. Complete fertility testing to assess your current fertility potential and determine the best preservation approach for your situation.

Complete required infectious disease screening and medical history review. Sign informed consent documents outlining the freezing process, storage options, and future use of your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos.
Provide a semen sample through ejaculation in a private collection room. If needed, multiple samples can be collected on different days to maximize the amount of sperm stored.
Your sperm sample is analyzed for count, motility, and quality. It is then processed and frozen using specialized cryoprotectants and stored in secure liquid nitrogen tanks.

paths.title: Egg Freezing
paths.description: Preserve fertility by freezing unfertilized eggs
paths.suitable_for: Delaying childbearing, before cancer treatment, or medical conditions

steps.overview: Meet with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals and timeline. Complete fertility testing to assess your current fertility potential and determine the best preservation approach for your situation.

Complete required infectious disease screening and medical history review. Sign informed consent documents outlining the freezing process, storage options, and future use of your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos.
Take daily fertility medication injections for 8-12 days to stimulate your ovaries. Attend regular monitoring appointments so your doctor can track egg development and adjust medications as needed.
Under light sedation, your doctor uses ultrasound guidance to retrieve eggs from your ovaries through a thin needle. The procedure takes 15-30 minutes, followed by 1-2 hours of recovery time.
Eggs are assessed for maturity and quality. Mature eggs are immediately flash-frozen using vitrification (ultra-rapid freezing) to maximize survival rates when thawed in the future.

Complete storage consent forms and set up annual storage fee payments. Discuss whether additional freezing cycles are recommended based on your age and goals. Review the process for using your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos in the future.

paths.title: Embryo Freezing With Partner
paths.description: Create and freeze embryos with partner's sperm
paths.suitable_for: Couples planning to delay pregnancy

steps.overview: Meet with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals and timeline. Complete fertility testing to assess your current fertility potential and determine the best preservation approach for your situation.

Complete required infectious disease screening and medical history review. Sign informed consent documents outlining the freezing process, storage options, and future use of your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos.
Provide a semen sample through ejaculation in a private collection room. If needed, multiple samples can be collected on different days to maximize the amount of sperm stored.
Your sperm sample is analyzed for count, motility, and quality. It is then processed and frozen using specialized cryoprotectants and stored in secure liquid nitrogen tanks.

paths.title: Embryo Freezing With Donor Sperm
paths.description: Create and freeze embryos using donor sperm
paths.suitable_for: Single individuals wanting embryos for future use

steps.overview: Meet with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals and timeline. Complete fertility testing to assess your current fertility potential and determine the best preservation approach for your situation.

Complete required infectious disease screening and medical history review. Sign informed consent documents outlining the freezing process, storage options, and future use of your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos.
Provide a semen sample through ejaculation in a private collection room. If needed, multiple samples can be collected on different days to maximize the amount of sperm stored.
Your sperm sample is analyzed for count, motility, and quality. It is then processed and frozen using specialized cryoprotectants and stored in secure liquid nitrogen tanks.

paths.title: Emergency Fertility Preservation
paths.description: Rapid preservation before cancer treatment
paths.suitable_for: Cancer patients needing immediate treatment

steps.overview: Emergency consultation with fertility specialist who coordinates with your oncology team. Rapid fertility assessment and fast-tracked infectious disease screening. Discuss preservation options that fit your cancer treatment timeline.

Start fertility medications immediately using a "random-start" protocol (can begin any day of your cycle). Daily monitoring to optimize egg development while minimizing delays to your cancer treatment. Trigger shot when ready.
Priority scheduling for egg retrieval (under sedation) or sperm collection (in private room). Same-day processing to minimize time before starting cancer treatment.
Eggs or embryos are immediately frozen using vitrification and stored securely. All storage documentation is completed efficiently to avoid delaying cancer treatment.

paths.title: Ovarian Tissue Cryopreservation
paths.description: Experimental preservation of ovarian tissue
paths.suitable_for: Prepubertal girls or when time doesn't allow for egg freezing

steps.overview: Meet with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals and timeline. Complete fertility testing to assess your current fertility potential and determine the best preservation approach for your situation.

Complete required infectious disease screening and medical history review. Sign informed consent documents outlining the freezing process, storage options, and future use of your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos.

Testicular tissue or sperm collection through surgical procedure or semen collection, depending on the patient's age and development. For prepubertal patients, testicular tissue biopsy is performed. For post-pubertal patients, semen collection is standard.
Eggs are assessed for maturity and quality. Mature eggs are immediately flash-frozen using vitrification (ultra-rapid freezing) to maximize survival rates when thawed in the future.

Complete storage consent forms and set up annual storage fee payments. Discuss whether additional freezing cycles are recommended based on your age and goals. Review the process for using your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos in the future.

paths.title: Prepubertal Fertility Preservation
paths.description: Experimental options for children
paths.suitable_for: Children facing gonadotoxic treatments

steps.overview: Meet with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals and timeline. Complete fertility testing to assess your current fertility potential and determine the best preservation approach for your situation.

Complete required infectious disease screening and medical history review. Sign informed consent documents outlining the freezing process, storage options, and future use of your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos.

Testicular tissue or sperm collection through surgical procedure or semen collection, depending on the patient's age and development. For prepubertal patients, testicular tissue biopsy is performed. For post-pubertal patients, semen collection is standard.
Eggs are assessed for maturity and quality. Mature eggs are immediately flash-frozen using vitrification (ultra-rapid freezing) to maximize survival rates when thawed in the future.

Complete storage consent forms and set up annual storage fee payments. Discuss whether additional freezing cycles are recommended based on your age and goals. Review the process for using your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos in the future.

paths.title: Anonymous Embryo Donation Cycle
paths.description: Using pre-created embryos from anonymous donors
paths.suitable_for: Patients requiring donor embryos from anonymous sources

steps.overview: Complete fertility evaluation including medical history, comprehensive testing, infectious disease screening, and detailed counseling about the IVF process, success rates, and what to expect.
Your doctor selects the best medication protocol for your situation. Complete baseline ultrasound and bloodwork to confirm you are ready to start. Learn how to administer your fertility medications.

Your doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into your uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. This is a quick, painless procedure. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use.

Begin progesterone supplementation to support the uterine lining. Wait 9-14 days after transfer, then return for a blood pregnancy test. If pregnant, you will have early monitoring ultrasounds before graduating to regular prenatal care.

paths.suitable_for: Patients using their own previously frozen eggs with partner sperm, particularly when egg shell hardening requires ICSI

paths.description: Comprehensive IVF protocol using previously frozen oocytes with donor sperm and ICSI - includes donor selection, endometrial preparation, egg thawing, fertilization, and embryo transfer
paths.suitable_for: Single women or patients with male factor infertility using their own previously frozen eggs with donor sperm

steps.overview: Meet with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals and timeline. Complete fertility testing to assess your current fertility potential and determine the best preservation approach for your situation.

paths.title: Donor Egg IVF with ICSI
paths.description: Comprehensive IVF protocol using previously frozen donor eggs with ICSI fertilization - includes donor selection, recipient preparation, egg thawing, fertilization, and embryo transfer
paths.suitable_for: Patients with diminished ovarian reserve, advanced maternal age, or genetic concerns using donor eggs with ICSI

steps.overview: Complete fertility evaluation including medical history, comprehensive testing, infectious disease screening, and detailed counseling about the IVF process, success rates, and what to expect.
Your doctor selects the best medication protocol for your situation. Complete baseline ultrasound and bloodwork to confirm you are ready to start. Learn how to administer your fertility medications.

Take daily fertility medication injections for 8-12 days to stimulate your ovaries to produce multiple eggs. Attend regular monitoring appointments (ultrasounds and bloodwork) so your doctor can adjust medications and track egg development.
Sperm is collected and prepared. Mature eggs are fertilized using ICSI (injecting one sperm into each egg). The next day, the embryologist checks to see how many eggs fertilized successfully.

Fertilized eggs (embryos) are cultured in the lab for 3-6 days. The embryology team monitors their development daily and grades their quality. If you are doing genetic testing (PGT), embryos are biopsied on day 5-6.

Your doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into your uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. This is a quick, painless procedure. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use.

Begin progesterone supplementation to support the uterine lining. Wait 9-14 days after transfer, then return for a blood pregnancy test. If pregnant, you will have early monitoring ultrasounds before graduating to regular prenatal care.

paths.title: Sperm Freezing (Non-Cancer)
paths.description: Preserve your fertility by banking sperm for future use - for medical reasons, before vasectomy, partner travel, or declining sperm quality
paths.suitable_for: Men who want to preserve fertility before medical treatments, vasectomy, military deployment/travel, or those experiencing declining sperm quality

steps.overview: Meet with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals and timeline. Complete fertility testing to assess your current fertility potential and determine the best preservation approach for your situation.

Complete storage consent forms and set up annual storage fee payments. Discuss whether additional freezing cycles are recommended based on your age and goals. Review the process for using your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos in the future.

Complete required infectious disease screening and medical history review. Sign informed consent documents outlining the freezing process, storage options, and future use of your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos.
Take daily fertility medication injections for 8-12 days to stimulate your ovaries. Attend regular monitoring appointments so your doctor can track egg development and adjust medications as needed.
Under light sedation, your doctor uses ultrasound guidance to retrieve eggs from your ovaries through a thin needle. The procedure takes 15-30 minutes, followed by 1-2 hours of recovery time.
Eggs are assessed for maturity and quality. Mature eggs are immediately flash-frozen using vitrification (ultra-rapid freezing) to maximize survival rates when thawed in the future.

Complete storage consent forms and set up annual storage fee payments. Discuss whether additional freezing cycles are recommended based on your age and goals. Review the process for using your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos in the future.

paths.title: Gender Transition - Sperm Preservation
paths.description: Comprehensive fertility preservation protocol for transgender men and non-binary individuals before gender-affirming hormone therapy or surgery - includes gender-affirming care and family planning support
paths.suitable_for: Transgender men or non-binary individuals assigned male at birth planning to start testosterone or undergo gender-affirming surgery

steps.overview: Meet with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals and timeline. Complete fertility testing to assess your current fertility potential and determine the best preservation approach for your situation.
topic_refs: Before Gender-Affirming Hormone Therapy or Surgery

steps.overview: Complete required infectious disease screening and medical history review. Sign informed consent documents outlining the freezing process, storage options, and future use of your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos.
Provide a semen sample through ejaculation in a private collection room. If needed, multiple samples can be collected on different days to maximize the amount of sperm stored.
topic_refs: Before Gender-Affirming Hormone Therapy or Surgery

steps.overview: Your sperm sample is analyzed for count, motility, and quality. It is then processed and frozen using specialized cryoprotectants and stored in secure liquid nitrogen tanks.

Complete storage consent forms and set up annual storage fee payments. Discuss whether additional freezing cycles are recommended based on your age and goals. Review the process for using your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos in the future.
topic_refs: Before Gender-Affirming Hormone Therapy or Surgery

paths.title: Sperm Preservation - On Testosterone
paths.description: Preserve fertility for transgender women already on testosterone hormone therapy requiring temporary hormone cessation and specialized protocols
paths.suitable_for: Transgender women on estrogen therapy who want to preserve fertility potential through sperm banking

steps.overview: Complete fertility evaluation including medical history, comprehensive testing, infectious disease screening, and detailed counseling about the IVF process, success rates, and what to expect.
topic_refs: Before Gender-Affirming Hormone Therapy or Surgery

steps.overview: Your doctor selects the best medication protocol for your situation. Complete baseline ultrasound and bloodwork to confirm you are ready to start. Learn how to administer your fertility medications.

Sperm is collected and prepared. Mature eggs are fertilized using conventional IVF (mixing sperm and eggs together). The next day, the embryologist checks to see how many eggs fertilized successfully.
topic_refs: Before Gender-Affirming Hormone Therapy or Surgery

steps.overview: Your doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into your uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. This is a quick, painless procedure. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use.

paths.title: Sperm Preservation - On Estrogen

paths.suitable_for: Transgender women on estrogen therapy who want to preserve fertility potential through sperm banking

paths.title: Male Oncofertility - Sperm Banking
paths.description: Urgent sperm cryopreservation for men facing gonadotoxic cancer treatments including chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or surgical interventions affecting fertility
paths.suitable_for: Post-pubertal males diagnosed with cancer requiring chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or surgical treatments that may compromise fertility

steps.overview: Emergency consultation with fertility specialist who coordinates with your oncology team. Rapid fertility assessment and fast-tracked infectious disease screening. Discuss preservation options that fit your cancer treatment timeline.

Start fertility medications immediately using a "random-start" protocol (can begin any day of your cycle). Daily monitoring to optimize egg development while minimizing delays to your cancer treatment. Trigger shot when ready.
Priority scheduling for semen collection in a private room. Same-day processing and cryopreservation to minimize time before starting cancer treatment.
Eggs or embryos are immediately frozen using vitrification and stored securely. All storage documentation is completed efficiently to avoid delaying cancer treatment.
Coordinate with your oncology team to begin cancer treatment immediately. Your fertility specialist will provide information about using your preserved fertility after cancer treatment is complete.

paths.title: Excess Embryo Freezing
paths.description: Cryopreservation of surplus high-quality embryos from fresh IVF cycle using vitrification protocols for future family building
paths.suitable_for: Couples with multiple good-quality embryos remaining after fresh embryo transfer who want to preserve options for future pregnancies

Complete storage consent forms and set up annual storage fee payments. Discuss whether additional freezing cycles are recommended based on your age and goals. Review the process for using your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos in the future.

paths.title: Embryo Freezing for Genetic Testing
paths.description: Freeze-all cycle with embryo biopsy for preimplantation genetic testing (PGT-A, PGT-M, or PGT-SR) requiring cryopreservation while awaiting genetic analysis results
paths.suitable_for: Couples requiring genetic testing on embryos for chromosomal abnormalities, single gene disorders, or structural rearrangements before transfer

steps.overview: Meet with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals and timeline. Complete fertility testing to assess your current fertility potential and determine the best preservation approach for your situation.
topic_refs: Preimplantation Genetic Testing for Structural Rearrangements (PGT-SR)

steps.overview: Complete required infectious disease screening and medical history review. Sign informed consent documents outlining the freezing process, storage options, and future use of your frozen eggs/sperm/embryos.

paths.suitable_for: Patients with medical conditions preventing safe fresh embryo transfer including high OHSS risk, endometrial abnormalities, or systemic medical issues

paths.description: Strategic embryo banking through multiple IVF cycles to preserve fertility options for planned future pregnancies and genetically-related siblings
paths.suitable_for: Couples planning multiple children who want to preserve fertility at current age, especially those in mid-30s or with anticipated future fertility decline

steps.overview: Meet with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals and timeline. Complete fertility testing to assess your current fertility potential and determine the best preservation approach for your situation.

paths.description: Emergency oocyte cryopreservation using random-start ovarian stimulation protocols for women requiring urgent cancer treatment within 2-4 weeks
paths.suitable_for: Women of reproductive age diagnosed with cancer requiring chemotherapy or radiation therapy that may compromise ovarian function

steps.overview: Emergency consultation with fertility specialist who coordinates with your oncology team. Rapid fertility assessment and fast-tracked infectious disease screening. Discuss preservation options that fit your cancer treatment timeline.

Start fertility medications immediately using a "random-start" protocol (can begin any day of your cycle). Daily monitoring to optimize egg development while minimizing delays to your cancer treatment. Trigger shot when ready.

Eggs or embryos are immediately frozen using vitrification and stored securely. All storage documentation is completed efficiently to avoid delaying cancer treatment.
Coordinate with your oncology team to begin cancer treatment immediately. Your fertility specialist will provide information about using your preserved fertility after cancer treatment is complete.

paths.description: Emergency embryo creation and cryopreservation using partner sperm with random-start ovarian stimulation for women requiring urgent cancer treatment within 2-4 weeks
paths.suitable_for: Women with committed male partners diagnosed with cancer requiring chemotherapy or radiation that may compromise ovarian function

Start fertility medications immediately using a "random-start" protocol (can begin any day of your cycle). Daily monitoring to optimize egg development while minimizing delays to your cancer treatment. Trigger shot when ready.

paths.suitable_for: Single women diagnosed with cancer or women whose partners cannot participate in fertility preservation requiring chemotherapy or radiation within 2-4 weeks

steps.overview: Emergency consultation with fertility specialist who coordinates with your oncology team. Rapid fertility assessment and fast-tracked infectious disease screening. Discuss preservation options that fit your cancer treatment timeline.

Start fertility medications immediately using a "random-start" protocol (can begin any day of your cycle). Daily monitoring to optimize egg development while minimizing delays to your cancer treatment. Trigger shot when ready.
If creating embryos, eggs are fertilized using partner or donor sperm. Fertilization is confirmed the next day.
Eggs or embryos are immediately frozen using vitrification and stored securely. All storage documentation is completed efficiently to avoid delaying cancer treatment.
Coordinate with your oncology team to begin cancer treatment immediately. Your fertility specialist will provide information about using your preserved fertility after cancer treatment is complete.

paths.title: Oncofertility - Ovarian Tissue Freezing
paths.description: Ovarian tissue cryopreservation for women requiring immediate cancer treatment when conventional fertility preservation methods are not feasible due to time constraints or patient age
paths.suitable_for: Prepubertal girls and women requiring immediate cancer treatment who cannot delay for ovarian stimulation or who have cancers excluding other preservation methods

steps.overview: Emergency consultation with fertility specialist who coordinates with your oncology team. Rapid fertility assessment and fast-tracked infectious disease screening. Discuss preservation options that fit your cancer treatment timeline.

Start fertility medications immediately using a "random-start" protocol (can begin any day of your cycle). Daily monitoring to optimize egg development while minimizing delays to your cancer treatment. Trigger shot when ready.
Priority scheduling for egg retrieval under sedation. Same-day processing to minimize time before starting cancer treatment.
Eggs or embryos are immediately frozen using vitrification and stored securely. All storage documentation is completed efficiently to avoid delaying cancer treatment.
Coordinate with your oncology team to begin cancer treatment immediately. Your fertility specialist will provide information about using your preserved fertility after cancer treatment is complete.

paths.title: Frozen Embryo Transfer (FET) Cycle
paths.description: Transfer previously frozen embryos using your own or a gestational carrier's uterus. This is one of the most common IVF cycle types, used when embryos were frozen from a previous cycle or after genetic testing.
paths.suitable_for: Patients with frozen embryos from a previous IVF cycle, those who did elective freezing ('freeze-all'), or those who completed genetic testing on embryos

steps.overview: Schedule a consultation with your fertility doctor to review your frozen embryos, discuss the transfer plan, and update any medical history. Your doctor will review embryo quality, recommend how many to transfer, and create a personalized medication protocol.

Take prescribed medications (typically estrogen and progesterone) to prepare your uterine lining for embryo implantation. Your clinic will monitor your lining thickness through ultrasounds to ensure optimal conditions for transfer.

Once your uterine lining reaches the ideal thickness (usually 8mm+), your transfer date will be scheduled. You'll receive specific instructions about when to start progesterone support and what to do on transfer day.

On transfer day, the embryology lab will thaw your embryo(s). The transfer procedure is quick and typically painless, similar to a pap smear. The embryo(s) are placed into your uterus using a thin catheter guided by ultrasound.

Continue taking progesterone and any other prescribed medications to support potential implantation. This is called the 'two-week wait' - the time between transfer and your pregnancy test. Follow all medication instructions carefully during this critical time.

Approximately 9-12 days after transfer, you'll have a blood test to check for pregnancy (beta hCG test). If positive, you'll continue medications and have repeat blood tests and ultrasounds. If negative, your doctor will discuss next steps.

paths.title: Using Your Frozen Eggs
paths.description: Ready to use the eggs you previously froze? This pathway guides you through thawing your eggs, fertilization, and transferring the resulting embryos. Whether you froze eggs for medical or elective reasons, this is your roadmap to using them.
paths.suitable_for: Patients who previously froze eggs and are now ready to attempt pregnancy

steps.overview: Schedule a consultation with your fertility doctor to discuss using your frozen eggs. Review your medical history, update any health changes since freezing, and discuss sperm source options. Your doctor will explain success rates based on your age at freezing and number of eggs available.

Decide on your sperm source: partner sperm, donor sperm from a bank, or a known donor. If using partner sperm, your partner will provide a sample. If using donor sperm, you'll select a donor and complete necessary legal paperwork.

The embryology lab will carefully thaw your frozen eggs. ICSI (intracytoplasmic sperm injection) is typically used to fertilize thawed eggs, as it has higher success rates than conventional fertilization. Your clinic will report how many eggs survived the thaw and were successfully fertilized.

Fertilized eggs (now embryos) will be cultured in the lab for 3-6 days. The embryology team monitors their development and grades them for quality. You may choose to do genetic testing (PGT) on embryos before transfer.

While embryos develop, you'll take medications to prepare your uterine lining. Once ready, one or more embryos will be transferred into your uterus in a quick, usually painless procedure. Any remaining quality embryos can be frozen for future use.

Continue taking progesterone support medications during the two-week wait. Approximately 9-12 days after transfer, you'll have a blood pregnancy test. If positive, you'll continue medications and have follow-up monitoring. If negative, your doctor will discuss next steps and remaining frozen materials.

paths.title: Using Your Frozen Sperm
paths.description: Use sperm you previously froze for fertility treatment. This pathway helps you coordinate thawing your frozen sperm with your partner's cycle for IUI or IVF treatment.
paths.suitable_for: Patients with previously frozen sperm who are ready to use it for fertility treatment with a partner or gestational carrier

steps.overview: Schedule a consultation with your fertility doctor to discuss using your frozen sperm. Review your sperm analysis from the time of freezing, discuss treatment options (IUI vs IVF), and create a plan coordinated with your partner's cycle.

Based on your partner's fertility evaluation and sperm quality, your doctor will recommend either IUI or IVF. IUI may be appropriate if your partner has open fallopian tubes and regular cycles. IVF may be recommended for more complex cases or lower sperm parameters.

Your partner will begin cycle monitoring or ovarian stimulation depending on whether you're doing IUI or IVF. The clinic will track follicle development and coordinate the timing of sperm thaw with either insemination (IUI) or egg retrieval (IVF).

On the day of your partner's IUI or egg retrieval, the lab will thaw your frozen sperm sample. The sperm will be washed and prepared for insemination or fertilization. The lab will assess post-thaw sperm quality and quantity.

For IUI: Prepared sperm is placed directly into your partner's uterus. For IVF: Sperm is used to fertilize eggs in the lab, typically using ICSI if sperm count is limited. Your clinic will guide you through the specific pathway you've chosen.

After the two-week wait, your partner will have a pregnancy test. If positive, continue with prenatal care. If negative, discuss next steps with your doctor, including whether you have additional frozen sperm samples for future attempts.

paths.title: Transitioning from IUI to IVF
paths.description: Moving from IUI to IVF is one of the most common transitions in fertility treatment. This pathway helps you understand why your doctor is recommending IVF, what to expect, and how to prepare for the next phase of your journey.
paths.suitable_for: Patients who have attempted IUI (usually 3-6 cycles) without success and are considering or have been recommended to move to IVF

steps.overview: Failed IUI cycles don't mean you did anything wrong. Many factors affect IUI success, including timing, egg quality, sperm quality, and unknown factors. Your doctor will review your IUI cycles to identify any patterns and explain why IVF may offer better chances given your specific situation.

IVF provides greater control and visibility than IUI. With IVF, fertilization happens in the lab where it can be monitored, embryos can be graded and tested, and the best embryo(s) are selected for transfer. Your doctor will explain how IVF addresses the limitations of IUI for your specific diagnosis.

IVF is a significant financial investment. Meet with your clinic's financial counselor to understand costs, review insurance coverage, explore payment plans, and learn about medication assistance programs. Understanding the financial picture upfront helps you plan and reduces stress.

Schedule an IVF consultation to create your personalized treatment plan. Your doctor may order additional testing such as updated hormone levels, antral follicle count, or genetic carrier screening. This is also the time to ask all your questions about the IVF process.

Your care team will create a customized IVF protocol based on your age, ovarian reserve, and previous treatment response. You'll learn about your medication protocol, how to do injections, what to expect during monitoring appointments, and timeline for your cycle.

Once you're ready emotionally and financially, and all testing is complete, you'll start your first IVF cycle. The clinic will coordinate timing with your menstrual cycle and walk you through each step. You'll transition to the appropriate IVF pathway based on your specific treatment plan.

paths.title: Transitioning to Donor Eggs After Failed IVF
paths.description: After multiple unsuccessful IVF cycles with your own eggs, moving to donor eggs can be an emotionally complex decision. This pathway provides guidance on understanding donor egg options, making informed decisions, and preparing for this next phase of your journey.
paths.suitable_for: Patients who have had unsuccessful IVF cycles with their own eggs and are considering or have been recommended to use donor eggs

steps.overview: Meet with your doctor to discuss why donor eggs are being recommended and understand the success rates. Donor egg IVF typically has higher success rates because the eggs come from younger donors, but it represents a significant shift in your journey that deserves thoughtful consideration.

You'll need to decide between using an anonymous donor from an agency/bank, or a known donor (friend or family member). Each option has different medical, legal, emotional, and logistical considerations. Your clinic can help you understand the pros and cons of each approach.

Donor egg IVF involves additional costs beyond standard IVF, including donor compensation, agency fees, legal contracts, and sometimes donor medications. Meet with a financial counselor to understand all costs and explore financing options. Some insurance plans provide limited coverage.

Donor egg arrangements require legal contracts to establish parental rights and outline all parties' responsibilities. You'll work with a reproductive attorney to ensure proper documentation, whether using a known or anonymous donor. This step protects everyone involved.

If using an anonymous donor, you'll review donor profiles including physical characteristics, medical history, education, and sometimes photos or personal essays. If using a known donor, they'll undergo medical and psychological screening. Take time to find the right match for your family.

Once your donor is selected and all legal/medical clearances are complete, your clinic will coordinate the cycle. The donor will undergo ovarian stimulation while you prepare your uterine lining. Timing is carefully orchestrated so embryos can be transferred to you fresh or frozen for later use.

paths.title: Egg Freezing for Transgender Men
paths.description: Preserve your fertility options before starting testosterone therapy or other gender-affirming treatments. This pathway is designed specifically for transgender men (assigned female at birth) who want to freeze eggs before medical transition.
paths.suitable_for: Transgender men who have not yet started testosterone therapy and wish to preserve fertility before beginning gender-affirming hormone treatment

steps.overview: Meet with a fertility doctor experienced in transgender care to discuss egg freezing before testosterone. You'll review the timeline, process, and how to coordinate with your gender-affirming care plan. The goal is to preserve fertility while minimizing delays to your transition.
topic_refs: Before Gender-Affirming Hormone Therapy or Surgery

steps.overview: Your fertility clinic will coordinate with your endocrinologist or gender care provider to ensure the egg freezing cycle doesn't interfere with your transition plans. If you've already started testosterone, you may need to temporarily pause it before the egg freezing cycle.
topic_refs: Before Gender-Affirming Hormone Therapy or Surgery

steps.overview: Complete fertility testing to assess your ovarian reserve and overall reproductive health. This includes bloodwork (AMH, FSH, estradiol) and an ultrasound to count follicles. These tests determine your expected response to ovarian stimulation medications.

Take injectable fertility medications to stimulate your ovaries to produce multiple eggs in one cycle. You'll have frequent monitoring appointments (ultrasounds and bloodwork) to track follicle growth. The stimulation phase typically lasts 10-14 days.

When follicles are mature, you'll have the egg retrieval procedure under light sedation. A doctor uses ultrasound guidance to collect eggs from your ovaries through the vaginal wall. The procedure takes about 20-30 minutes, and you'll go home the same day.

Eggs are immediately frozen using vitrification (flash-freezing) and stored in liquid nitrogen. You'll receive a report on how many mature eggs were frozen. Eggs can remain frozen indefinitely. The clinic will discuss storage fees and annual contracts.

After recovery from egg retrieval (typically 1-2 weeks), you can proceed with starting or resuming testosterone therapy and other gender-affirming treatments. Your eggs are safely stored and can be used in the future if you decide to pursue biological parenthood.
topic_refs: Before Gender-Affirming Hormone Therapy or Surgery
